concern: Ive always dreamed of leaving the state and attending a musical theatre college to pursue my dreams, but im scared to apply to the colleges I want to because my roommate and best friend who took me in when I struggled living with my parents says he is not ready to move away with me. I have always hoped he could come with me but I think ive always known deep down he was never going to. I dont usually pour my feelings out on social media but when he brought this up to me, I felt so much anger and frustration and sadness and pain. I can't imagine leaving him behind after he has provided such a comfortable life for me, not to mention my pets and sister who is still with my mom. I feel so distraught when I think about leaving all by myself because I had always hoped I could have my best friend come with me. I'm so scared that we will drift apart, even though we have been friends all throughout middle and highschool. I dont really have any other friends, maybe a few coworkers I talk to at work, but he is the only person I can say is genuinely close to me. I worry I wont bond with anyone like I did him when I leave for college and will only remain close acquaintances with potential college friends. Everywhere I look online I see the same things about taking opportunities to meet new people and not dwell on past relationships, staying in touch when you have time, but the thought alone makes me so incredibly upset. I haven't even applied to any of my dream colleges yet and im sitting here crying thinking about the outcomes, even though I dont know if I will even get in or attend these colleges until the fall. Im so angry and upset that he won't come with me but at the same time Im so upset at the thought that I will miss him terribly. Part of me feels like losing touch is inevitable and I dont know how to handle it. He and his family has done so much for me and to just move on and forget that feels so wrong. Before we started living together, I felt so incredibly alone and I dont want to feel so isolated again. Im coping terribly at the thought alone and I have no clue how i'll even manage to cope. I dont want to put my whole life on hold to wait and move on until he's ready too, but doing what I want to do feels so painful.

dialogue_total.statement: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed. Can you tell me a bit more about what's going on?

I'm feeling really torn about pursuing my dream of attending a musical theatre college out of state, mainly because it involves leaving my best friend behind. This is making me anxious about losing that close connection and ending up feeling isolated again.

Its clear that your friendship is incredibly important to you. At the same time, it sounds like youre worried about missing out on your dream if you stay. Its tough to be caught between two things that matter so much.

Yes, it's incredibly difficult to weigh my dream against the risk of losing my closest friendship. I keep worrying that pursuing this path will leave me feeling isolated all over again, even though I know it's what I want deep down.

It's natural to feel conflicted when faced with a decision like this. It takes courage to pursue your dreams, but it's also important to consider the impact on your relationships. Perhaps we can explore ways to maintain your connection with your best friend while still pursuing your passion?

I appreciate the idea of finding ways to stay connected, but I'm really worried that distance will make our friendship fade no matter what we try. It's hard for me to imagine building that same level of closeness with anyone else if I go.

It's understandable that the thought of losing such a valuable connection is causing you anxiety. However, it's worth considering that strong friendships can endure distance and change if both parties are willing to put in effort. Would you like to discuss some strategies that might help maintain your bond, even if you choose to attend the out-of-state college?

Yes, I'd like to discuss some strategies for maintaining my friendship. I'm just worried that even with effort, the distance might still lead to us growing apart and leaving me feeling isolated again.

Let's start by exploring communication methods that can help you stay connected with your friend, such as scheduling regular video calls or virtual hangouts. Consistency in communication can help maintain the closeness you value in your friendship.

 That's a good idea. I think we could commit to weekly video calls and maybe even watch movies or shows together online. I'm still worried though, that it won't be the same as being in person.

 It's true that virtual interactions can't fully replace in-person experiences, but they can help bridge the distance. Another idea is to plan visits during breaks or long weekends, giving you both something to look forward to and an opportunity to spend time together in person.

 I like the idea of planning visits, and I think we could make that work. I guess I'm just scared that our lives will change so much that we won't be able to relate to each other anymore.

I appreciate the suggestion of planning visits, as it could help keep our connection alive. Still, I'm worried that our diverging paths in life might make it difficult to maintain that same level of understanding and closeness we have now.

It's natural to be concerned about how life changes might affect your friendship. However, remember that true friends can grow and evolve together, even if their paths diverge. It might require extra effort and understanding, but the bond you've built can serve as a strong foundation for adapting to these changes. Would you like to discuss ways to embrace and support each other's growth while maintaining your connection?
Yes, I'd like to discuss ways to embrace and support each other's growth while staying connected. I'm concerned that the changes in our lives might make it hard to keep that deep bond intact.

One approach could be openly discussing your fears and expectations about how your friendship might evolve. By acknowledging these concerns together, you can establish a mutual understanding and create a plan for maintaining your bond. This can also help foster a sense of trust and vulnerability, which can strengthen your connection.

 It sounds like a good idea to have an open conversation about our worries and expectations. I think it would be helpful for both of us to share our thoughts and come up with a plan together. I'm still a bit scared, but I know we care about each other, and that's a good starting point.

 Absolutely, having that open communication can help you both navigate the changes and reassure each other of your commitment to the friendship. Additionally, you can find new ways to bond over shared interests or experiences, even if they're different from what you've done in the past. This can help create a sense of excitement and growth within your friendship.

 That's true finding new shared interests could be a fun way to keep our bond strong. Maybe we could even start a book club or watch new shows together to discuss. I'm still anxious about the situation, but I feel a bit better knowing that we can work on this together.

That's a helpful reminder about finding new ways to connect it gives me hope that we can adapt and keep our friendship evolving. Even so, I'm still worried that the distance might slowly erode the closeness we've shared for so long.

Acknowledge the client's concerns and suggest exploring the idea of scheduling regular virtual hangouts or phone calls, ensuring consistent communication and a sense of closeness, even from a distance.

 That's a good idea. Setting up regular virtual hangouts or phone calls might help us feel more connected. I'll bring it up when we discuss our expectations and make a plan together.

 Encourage the client to consider that maintaining friendships can be challenging, but with effort and open communication, it's possible to preserve the bond they've built with their friend.

 You're right, it won't be easy, but I believe our friendship is worth the effort. We've been through a lot together, and I know we can make it work even if things change.
That's a reassuring thoughtI'm glad to hear that effort and communication can help sustain our bond. Still, I worry that the distance might make it harder to feel as connected as we do now.

In summary, it's important to remember that your friendship has a strong foundation, and by making a concerted effort to maintain open communication and find new ways to connect, you can help ensure that your bond remains resilient. Be sure to check in with each other regularly, and don't hesitate to share your feelings as they come up. I'm confident that your friendship can evolve and continue to thrive, even as you embark on this new chapter in your life. Let's plan to touch base in about a month to see how things are going and address any new concerns that may arise.

Thank you for the encouragement I'll try to stay proactive with communication to protect our friendship, but it's still hard to imagine not having him nearby every day. I look forward to checking in next month.
